commit_message:
Add spec for encrypt/decrypt function

Change-Id: I969de09ab348024e2f2e13f6a99b470e42e4da8e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican-specs refs/changes/89/598389/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================== Add Encrypt/Decrypt Operations ============================== Story: https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2003131 In order to use Barbican as a key manager for kubernetes, it is necessary to add an encrypt/decrypt functionality to Barbican. The basic idea here is to provide an API call which would accept a UUID for a key (in this case used as a KEK) that has already been stored or generated in barbican, an encryption algorithm and mode, and some small amount of data (the size of keys) to be encrypted. The API would retrive the KEK and return the encrypted data. No data would be stored. The decrypt call would be the inverse. The caller would provide the encrypted data, algorithm, mode and KEK ID, and the encrypted data, and would expect the unencrypted data to be returned. Problem Description =================== It could be valuable to use Barbican as a key management system (KMS) for kubernetes, centralizing secret management for Kubernetes on Openstack deployments. References [1,2] describe how kubernetes expects to interact with a KMS subsystem when encrypting data at rest. Reference [3] shows how one KMS plugin would be written. Basically, when data is to be encrypted, a data encryption key (DEK) is generated and sent to the KMS through an encrypt() function. The KMS is expected to encrypt the DEK with a Key Encryption Key (KEK) and pass back the encrypted DEK to be stored in etcd. When the data needs to be decrypted, kubernetes (or more specifically the kubernetes key management plugin) contacts the KMS and passes the encrypted data in a decrypt() call. The KMS is expected to return the decrypted DEK. Notice in all of this, the encrypted data is only stored in etcd. The KMS only stores the KEK (which never leaves the KMS). The corresponding encrypt/decrypt functions do not exist in the current Barbican API. This is a proposal to add this functionality. Proposed Change =============== Tow new calls will be added to the REST API - to do encryption and decryption. These are detailed in the "REST API Impact" section below. Its probably easiest to read that first to get a sense of the rest of the changes. Two corresponding functions encrypt_data() and decrypt_data() will be added to the Secret Store Plugin interface. In addtion, we should add a encrypt_supports() function to specify the supported encryption algorithms. The secret store should also provide a default_encryption_algotithm() function to define the default encryption algorithm. The likely encryption algorithms will be: fernet, aes_256_cbc, aes_128_cbc, aes_128_gcm, aes_256_gcm. In the initial implementation, we could only implement Fernet encryption using python-cryptography in the simple_crypto plugin. Other mechanisms could be added as required. REST API impact --------------- Two new calls will be added to the API. One to perform an encryption and one to perform a decryption. POST /v1/encrypt ################ Encrypts the payload (base64 encoded) with the referenced key using the requested algorithm. Returns the encrypted secret (base64 encoded), the algorithm used to do the encryption and any additional parameters (like an IV) needed to later decrypt. Attributes ********** +----------------------------+---------+-----------------------------------------------------+------------+ | Attribute Name | Type | Description | Default | +============================+=========+=====================================================+============+ | kek_uuid | string | (required) The UUID for the KEK to be used for the | None | | | | encryption. | | +----------------------------+---------+-----------------------------------------------------+------------+ | algorithm | string | (optional) Algorithm to be used for the encryption. | None | | | | The suggested list is provided below. | | +----------------------------+---------+-----------------------------------------------------+------------+ | payload | string | (required) The data to be encrypted. The data is | None | | | | expected to be base64 encoded | | +----------------------------+---------+-----------------------------------------------------+------------+ The possible algorithms could include: Fernet, AES_256_CBC, AES_128_CBC, AES_256_GCM, AES_128_GCM. If the algorithm is not provided, then the algorithm will be selected by the backend plugin. As described below, the secret store plugin will define the algorithms that it supports as well as the "default" algorithm. Recall that the secret store backend is selected as the global default backend, unless a specific backend is provided for the project in the project_secret_store table. Request: ******** .. code-block:: javascript POST /v1/encrypt Headers: Content-Type: application/json X-Auth-Token: <token> Content: { "kek_uuid": "{kek_uuid}", "payload": "YmVlcg==", } Response: ********* .. code-block:: javascript 200 OK { "algorithm": "fernet", "encrypted_payload": ""XdmYYxx==", "parameters: [] } HTTP Status Codes ***************** +------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | Code | Description | +======+=============================================================================+ | 200 | Successfully performed the encryption | +------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | 400 | Bad Request - possible reasons: | | | * bad key for algorithm | | | * invalid or unsupported algorithm for the secret store | | | * kek missing (or caller cannot reference) | | | * data to be encrypted is too long | +------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | 401 | Invalid X-Auth-Token or the token doesn't have permissions to this | | | operation. | +------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------+ POST /v1/decrypt ################ Decrypts the payload (base64 encoded) with the referenced key using the provided algorithm. Returns the encrypted secret (base64 encoded) and the algorithm used to do the encryption. Attributes ********** +----------------------------+---------+-----------------------------------------------------+------------+ | Attribute Name | Type | Description | Default | +============================+=========+=====================================================+============+ | kek_uuid | string | (required) The UUID for the KEK to be used for the | None | | | | decryption. | | +----------------------------+---------+-----------------------------------------------------+------------+ | algorithm | string | (required) Algorithm to be used for the decryption. | None | | | | This is the algorithm returned from calling encrypt | | +----------------------------+---------+-----------------------------------------------------+------------+ | parameters | dict | (optional) Any parameters needed to decrypt as | None | | | | provided by encrypt call. (eg. iv, if needed) | | +----------------------------+---------+-----------------------------------------------------+------------+ | encrypted_payload | string | (required) The data to be decrypted. The data is | None | | | | expected to be base64 encoded | | +----------------------------+---------+-----------------------------------------------------+------------+ Request: ******** .. code-block:: javascript POST /v1/decrypt Headers: Content-Type: application/json X-Auth-Token: <token> Content: { "kek_uuid": "{kek_uuid}", "algorithm": "fernet", "parameters: [], "encrypted_payload": "YmVlcg==", } Response: ********* .. code-block:: javascript 200 OK { "algorithm": "fernet", "encrypted_payload": ""XdmYYxx==" } HTTP Status Codes ***************** +------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | Code | Description | +======+=============================================================================+ | 200 | Successfully performed the decryption | +------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | 400 | Bad Request - possible reasons: | | | * bad key for algorithm | | | * invalid or unsupported algorithm for the secret store | | | * kek missing (or caller cannot reference) | | | * data to be decrypted is too long | +------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | 401 | Invalid X-Auth-Token or the token doesn't have permissions to this | | | operation. | +------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------+ Other API Changes ################# To make it easy for the client to determine a kek_uuid that is compatible with the default algorithm, the following API changes should also be done: * The secret_store API should be enhanced to provide the default/supported encryption algorithms on a GET operation. * The Order interface for symmetric keys will be enhanced to include a "usage" attribute. If the "usage" attribute is set to "default_encrypt", all algorithm/size/mode parameters will be ignored and the plugin will generate a key that can be used by the default encryption algorithm for that secret store. With the above changes, doing an encryption/decryption with Barbican should be quite straightforward, and should require no knowledge of the secret store backends available, or the algorithms available. The user would simply: * Send an order to generate an encryption key with usage="encrypt_decrypt". This will result in a KEK that is compatible with the default encryption algorithm for the available backend for the project. * Call encrypt with the kek_uuid and payload. This returns the encrypted payload, algorithm and any required parameters. * Call decrypt with the encrypted payload, kek_uuid, algorithm and parameters. As we are making API changes, we will need to consider how old/new clients will interact with old/new servers. Most likely, this will require API microversioning. Alternatives ------------ One could create a kubernetes plugin using the existing API by simply storing the DEK in Barbican when doing the encrypt() operation, and storing the UUID of the secret in etcd. When doing the decrypt() operation, the kubernetes plugin would simply retrieve the stored DEK. This really is a bit of a shoehorn though. And, as a new DEK is created for every encryption, it has the disadvantage of storing data about potentially hundreds of thousands of keys in two places -- the etcd database and the barbican database - which is certainly not ideal. Data model impact ----------------- As the data being encrypted/decrypted is not persisted to the database, there should be no data model impact. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications & Audit Impact ---------------------------- None, other than new potential audit events.. Python and Command Line Client Impact ------------------------------------- The new API calls (and the change to the Orders API) will need to be added to the python and command line clients. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- None. Work Items ---------- TBD Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= We'll need new unit and functional tests to validate the new functionality. As this functionality is used by other openstack services (DNSSEC maybe?), additional tests need to be added to barbican-tempest-tests. Documentation Impact ==================== This is all new functionality that needs to be documented. References ========== 1. https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/administer-cluster/encrypt-data/ 2. https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/administer-cluster/kms-provider/#implementing-a-kms-plugin 3. https://ritazh.com/using-azure-key-vault-for-kubernetes-data-encryption-d5eac8daee71

commit_message:
Set force_config_drive only when OVNMetadata is disabled

There are usecases when operator wants to talk to metadata API from
config-drive script (e.g. using curl to get data from metadata). That
means it makes sense to have OVN Metadata Agent deployed while forcing
config-drive to be used.

This patch sets force_config_drive to true only when OVNMetadataEnable
is set to false. If it's set to true then it doesn't touch
force_config_drive option, leaving it up to environment to define it.
(The default for force_config_drive is false.)

Closes-Bug: #1830179
Change-Id: Ib956ff2f521b9853c58eaa5500836c692dd9321d

the SQL shell 'mysql' currently cannot parse config under section

commit_message:
Write TLS config under section [client] in tripleo.cnf

the SQL shell 'mysql' currently cannot parse config under section
[tripleo] as option bind-address is not supported in mariadb (only
supported in mysql and PyMySQL).

Generate a proper TLS config under section [client] so that the
mysql shell can connect to the mysql server with the proper TLS
settings.

Change-Id: Icaaee64b6f491bf80fde2a8a44c6b28727493e13
Closes-Bug: #1829758

Change-Id: I49f4ca2b972a6052d870c2b92eb343f022787203

commit_message:
Add spec for signing database entries

Change-Id: I49f4ca2b972a6052d870c2b92eb343f022787203
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican-specs refs/changes/06/586606/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ===================== Sign Database Entries ===================== Story: https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2003131 To address the threat of an attacker gaining access to secrets by modiying ACL entries in the Barbican database, we propose to sign database entries when they are saved, and verify the entries when they are accessed. Problem Description =================== To address the threat of an attacker gaining access to secrets by modiying ACL entries in the Barbican database, we propose to sign database entries when they are saved, and verify the entries when they are accessed. There is a long standing security issue that was identified by the Security project whereby if an attacker has write access to the barbican database, they might be able to modify entries and obtain access to secrets. One way to do this, for instance, is to add or modify an ACL to provide access to a secret. In the same vein, it would be possible to deny users access to secrets. To prevent any process other than the Barbican process from writing to the database, we propose to sign the data in the barbican tables, and check the signature when the data is accessed. Proposed Change =============== A new version of various database objects - in particular, secrets and acls - will be provided. These new versions will include a field for an HMAC which will be computed when the object is stored, and checked when the object is accessed. If the data is found not to match its signature, then an exception should be raised and ultimately a 401 (500?) error thrown. The error should also be logged and audited. The symmetric key used to generate the HMAC will be stored in barbican.conf. Once the oslo config work is completed, that secret can be stored in a castellan compatible secret store and replaced by a castellan reference. This work requires the oslo versioned object work to be completed. The new objects will have new object versions, and the computation and checking of HMACs will depend on having a database with at least those versions. Alternatives ------------ As a mitigation, one could choose to deploy the Barbican database in a databse instance that is separate than those of the other Opestack services and try to restrict access to the Barbican service. There may be mechanisms provided by various databases to guarantee the integrity of DB entries, but I am currently unfamiiar with any. Data model impact ----------------- barbican-db-manage will be augmented to perform the following tasks: 1) generate and store a 256 bit AES key (DB HMAC key) in barbican.conf. 2) modify the relevant DB tables to add the extra field for the HMAC. 3) go through each DB entry and compute and store an HMAC. 4) update the versions for each of the database objects. Assuming that all of this conversion takes place while the process is online, a separate config option will probably be needed to turn off HMAC verification until all entries have been migrated. The migration process will look something like this: 1) option is added to barbican.conf to not check HMAC values. This could be done by barbican-db-manage 2) barbican-db-manage runs and generates the HMAC key, and modifies the DB tables and sets the new DB object versions. 3) All new or modified objects from this point are HMAC'ed automatically. 4) barbican-db-manage is run to check each db entry and compute the HMAC if it does not exist. It should be run again until no further entries are modified. 5) Operator then removes the option in barbican.conf to not check HMAC values, and restarts barbican. REST API impact --------------- As this is all on the backend, there should be no impact on the REST API, other than to make sure that the HMAC values are not exposed to the user through the API. Security impact --------------- This will improve the security of the system by preventing attacks by users that have write access to the database. The tradeoff is the need to store a signing key in barbican.conf. This will be mitigated by storing the key in a castellan based secret store when the oslo work is completed. Notifications & Audit Impact ---------------------------- If invalid entries are found, this may be symptoms of tampering. Audit events and notifications should be raised. Python and Command Line Client Impact ------------------------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ Each database access for the affected objects will require an additional signature checks. For instance, when getting a secret, we likely will need to verify signatures for an ACL entries as well as the secret entry itself. We should choose a signing and verification algorithm that is fast and efficient. Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- None. Work Items ---------- TBD Dependencies ============ * Oslo Versioned Objects work - rolling upgrades. Testing ======= Certainly, we will need to run the current unit and functional tests to confirm that DB access is still valid when the entries are signed. We'll also need to validate the migration process. Testing that access is denied and audit events are generated when the entry HMAC is invalid will be tricky, because it will require direct manipulation of database entries using SQL commands. Documentation Impact ==================== Most users should be unaffected by these changes. The migration process will need to be documented though. References ========== None.

commit_message:
Blueprint for making soft deletions optional

Barbican currently does soft deletions on some resources. This gives
the option for the admin to turn this off and enable hard deletions.

Change-Id: I0c90b2e787d4901b9687a2cd10836310c534ffe3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican-specs refs/changes/34/267034/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ==================================================== Make soft deletions optional (enable hard deletions) ==================================================== Blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/barbican/+spec/make-soft-deletions-optional Problem Description =================== Currently, barbican uses soft deletions when deleting some resources. The entry in the datbase is not removed but marked for deletion. A deployer may want to turn off this feature and have the entry removed from the database completely when deleting resources. Proposed Change =============== Add a variable in barbican.conf to make soft deletions optional. The default value will be True (Soft deletion will be used). Add documentation in a barbican garbage management wikipage for making soft deletions optional. Change model/repository code to read the variable from barbican.conf and either use soft deletions or hard deletions. Example barbican.conf: # Enables soft deletions and default is True. If a user deletes a resource # such as a secret, then the entry in the database will be flagged # for deletion. Otherwise if set to False, then the entry will be removed. enable_soft_deletions = True Alternatives ------------ 1. Do not make soft deletions optional and make hard deletions the default. 2. Create an API to give the user the optional to either to use soft deletions or hard deletions when doing a delete operation. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications & Audit Impact ---------------------------- None Python and Command Line Client Impact ------------------------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- If soft deletion is disabled, the user will not be able to restore any accidentaly deleted secrets. If they stored an encryption key in the secret and they accidently deleted the secret then they will lose their data. Performance Impact ------------------ More storage may be available since all deleted resources would be immediately removed from the database instead of being flagged for deletion. Database fragmentation may occur depending on database tuning. Other deployer impact --------------------- Deployer will need to decide if they want to use soft deletions or hard deletions. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: edtubill Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- Work Item 1: Add variable to barbican.conf, change model/repository code to read variable and either use soft or hard deletions. Add tests to check if variable is read and used correctly. Work Item 2: Create wiki page for garbage management for barbican and include information for making soft deletions optional. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit tests will be created to test out the code that reads the variable from barbican.conf. Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation of the variable will be added to a wiki page for barbican garbage management. The tables that are affected will be documented (what models are soft deletable). References ========== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/barbican/+spec/make-soft-deletions-optional

commit_message:
Replace orders quota with secrets reservation system

This blueprint specifies the current issues with order quota
enforcement and proposes the removal of the orders quota,
implementation of a secrets reservation system to handle secret
quota enforcement when creating orders, and implementation of
checks against the secrets quota at every step of order creation.

Orders can also take a significant amount of time to create (such as in
the case of certificates), which raises the question of whether there
will be any secrets available for the order when it is finished creating
(what if orders quota is greater than secrets
quota and the secrets quota is exceeded?).

This blueprint proposes removal of the orders quota, implementation of a
system to reserve secrets when an order is placed, and the
implementation of secret quota checks at every step of order creation
(when an order is placed, when a call to the plugin is made, and when a
secret is returned by the plugin).

Change-Id: Ic9381210208cc775c0622bf88eef1bf599aa1392
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican-specs refs/changes/98/311198/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Example Spec - The title of your blueprint ========================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/barbican/+spec/example Include the URL of your client blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/python-barbicanclient/example Introduction paragraph -- why are we doing anything? A single paragraph of prose that operators can understand. Some notes about using this template: * Your spec should be in ReSTructured text, like this template. * Please wrap text at 79 columns. * The filename in the git repository should match the launchpad URL, for example a URL of: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/barbican/+spec/awesome-thing should be named awesome-thing.rst * Please do not delete any of the sections in this template. If you have nothing to say for a whole section, just write: None * For help with syntax, see http://sphinx-doc.org/rest.html * To test out your formatting, build the docs using tox, or see: http://rst.ninjs.org * If you would like to provide a diagram with your spec, ascii diagrams are required. http://asciiflow.com/ is a very nice tool to assist with making ascii diagrams. The reason for this is that the tool used to review specs is based purely on plain text. Plain text will allow review to proceed without having to look at additional files which can not be viewed in gerrit. It will also allow inline feedback on the diagram itself. * If your specification proposes any changes to the Barbican REST API such as changing parameters which can be returned or accepted, or even the semantics of what happens when a client calls into the API, then you should add the APIImpact flag to the commit message. Specifications with the APIImpact flag can be found with the following query:: https://review.openstack.org/#/q/status:open+project:openstack/barbican-specs+message:apiimpact,n,z Problem Description =================== Currently, if secrets quota is not infinite, it is possible to create (secrets quota + orders quota) number of secrets via order creation, because the order quota enforcer does not take into account whether the secrets quota is full or not. This problem arises from the fact that the secrets quota is not checked when orders are placed. Orders can also take a significant amount of time to create (such as in the case of certificates), which raises the question of whether there will be any secrets available for the order when it is finished creating (what if orders quota is greater than secrets quota and the secrets quota is exceeded?). Proposed Change =============== This blueprint proposes removal of the orders quota, implementation of a system to reserve secrets when an order is placed, and the implementation of secret quota checks at every step of order creation (when an order is placed, when a call to the plugin is made, and when a secret is returned by the plugin). The orders quota option will need to be removed from the barbican.conf file and the orders quota project field will need to be removed from the database. The secrets reservation system will keep a "num_reserved_secrets" field in the database to keep track of the current number of reserved secrets. Different numbers of secrets will need to be reserved for each kind of order. For example, an RSA key pair requires 1 secret for public key + 1 secret for private key = 2 secrets. We can get the number of secrets that each type of order is worth from the database. When an order is placed, if num_reserved_secrets + new order secrets does not exceed the secrets quota, num_reserved_secrets is incremented by the new order's secrets. An ERROR is returned otherwise. After the order is placed and goes to plugin call, another check is made to compare the num_reserved_secrets to the secrets quota. It is assumed that at this point, the new order's number of secrets has already been added to num_reserved_secrets. If num_reserved_secrets is less than secrets quota, a call to the plugin to create a new secret is made. Otherwise, an ERROR is thrown and num_reserved_secrets is decremented by the number of secrets the order was worth. After the secret is returned from the plugin, make another check against the secrets quota to ensure that adding this secret will still not exceed secret quota. If the check passes, add the secret to the database. Otherwise, throw an ERROR. In both cases, the number of secrets that the order was worth is decremented from num_reserved_secrets. The checks described above will be disabled if the secrets quota is infinite. Alternatives ------------ We could keep the orders quota and check for both secrets quota and orders quota every time a order is created. These checks can also be made when the order is placed, when the plugin is called, and when the secret is returned from plugin. Orders quota is being removed to avoid confusion about its quota enforcement policy, as orders would essentially be many secrets and there is some overlap in the responsibilities of order and secret quota enforcement. Data model impact ----------------- The orders quota field will need to be removed from the orders project model. A new field, called "num_reserved_secrets", will need to be added to the secrets project model. * What new data objects and/or database schema changes is this going to require? * What database migrations will accompany this change (if any)? * How will the initial set of new data objects be generated? For example, if you need to take into account existing keys, or modify other existing data describe how that will work. REST API impact --------------- * Specification for the method * A description of what the method does suitable for use in user documentation * Method type (POST/PUT/GET/DELETE) * Normal http response code(s) * Expected error http response code(s) * A description for each possible error code should be included describing semantic errors which can cause it such as inconsistent parameters supplied to the method, or when an instance is not in an appropriate state for the request to succeed. Errors caused by syntactic problems covered by the JSON schema defintion do not need to be included. * URL for the resource * Parameters which can be passed via the url * JSON schema definition for the body data if allowed * JSON schema definition for the response data if any * Example use case including typical API samples for both data supplied by the caller and the response * Discuss any policy changes, and discuss what things a deployer needs to think about when defining their policy. Example JSON schema definitions can be found in the Nova tree http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova/tree/nova/api/openstack/compute/schemas/v3 Note that the schema should be defined as restrictively as possible. Parameters which are required should be marked as such and only under exceptional circumstances should additional parameters which are not defined in the schema be permitted (eg additionaProperties should be False). Reuse of existing predefined parameter types such as regexps for passwords and user defined names is highly encouraged. Security impact --------------- Describe any potential security impact on the system. Some of the items to consider include: * Does this change touch sensitive data such as tokens, keys, or user data? * Does this change alter the API in a way that may impact security, such as a new way to access sensitive information or a new way to login? * Does this change involve cryptography or hashing? * Does this change require the use of sudo or any elevated privileges? * Does this change involve using or parsing user-provided data? This could be directly at the API level or indirectly such as changes to a cache layer. * Can this change enable a resource exhaustion attack, such as allowing a single API interaction to consume significant server resources? Some examples of this include launching subprocesses for each connection, or entity expansion attacks in XML. * Does this change change the need for auditing in any way? For more detailed guidance, please see the OpenStack Security Guidelines as a reference (https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Security/Guidelines). These guidelines are a work in progress and are designed to help you identify security best practices. For further information, feel free to reach out to the OpenStack Security Group at openstack-security@lists.openstack.org. Notifications & Audit Impact ---------------------------- Please specify any changes to notifications or auditing. Be that an extra notification, changes to an existing notification, or removing a notification. Python and Command Line Client Impact ------------------------------------- Please specify any changes to the python and command line clients (CLI). Consider the OpenStack unified clients as well as the soon to be deprecated Barbican clients. Other end user impact --------------------- Aside from the API, are there other ways a user will interact with this feature? * Does this change have an impact on python-novaclient? What does the user interface there look like? Performance Impact ------------------ The additional checks will add a very small constant-time impact on the order creation flow. Describe any potential performance impact on the system, for example how often will new code be called, and is there a major change to the calling pattern of existing code. Examples of things to consider here include: * A periodic task might look like a small addition but if it calls conductor or another service the load is multiplied by the number of nodes in the system. * Scheduler filters get called once per host for every instance being created, so any latency they introduce is linear with the size of the system. * A small change in a utility function or a commonly used decorator can have a large impacts on performance. * Calls which result in a database queries (whether direct or via conductor) can have a profound impact on performance when called in critical sections of the code. * Will the change include any locking, and if so what considerations are there on holding the lock? Other deployer impact --------------------- The order quota config option will be removed. No new config options will be added. Discuss things that will affect how you deploy and configure OpenStack that have not already been mentioned, such as: * What config options are being added? Should they be more generic than proposed (for example a flag that other hypervisor drivers might want to implement as well)? Are the default values ones which will work well in real deployments? * Is this a change that takes immediate effect after its merged, or is it something that has to be explicitly enabled? * If this change is a new binary, how would it be deployed? * Please state anything that those doing continuous deployment, or those upgrading from the previous release, need to be aware of. Also describe any plans to deprecate configuration values or features. For example, if we change the directory name that instances are stored in, how do we handle instance directories created before the change landed? Do we move them? Do we have a special case in the code? Do we assume that the operator will recreate all the instances in their cloud? Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: mperng Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- Work items or tasks -- break the feature up into the things that need to be done to implement it. Those parts might end up being done by different people, but we're mostly trying to understand the timeline for implementation. Dependencies ============ * Include specific references to specs and/or blueprints in nova, or in other projects, that this one either depends on or is related to. * If this requires functionality of another project that is not currently used by Nova (such as the glance v2 API when we previously only required v1), document that fact. * Does this feature require any new library dependencies or code otherwise not included in OpenStack? Or does it depend on a specific version of library? Testing ======= Please discuss how the change will be tested. We especially want to know what tempest tests will be added. It is assumed that unit test coverage will be added so that doesn't need to be mentioned explicitly, but discussion of why you think unit tests are sufficient and we don't need to add more tempest tests would need to be included. Is this untestable in gate given current limitations (specific hardware / software configurations available)? If so, are there mitigation plans (3rd party testing, gate enhancements, etc). Documentation Impact ==================== What is the impact on the docs team of this change? Some changes might require donating resources to the docs team to have the documentation updated. Don't repeat details discussed above, but please reference them here. References ========== Please add any useful references here. You are not required to have any reference. Moreover, this specification should still make sense when your references are unavailable. Examples of what you could include are: * Links to mailing list or IRC discussions * Links to notes from a summit session * Links to relevant research, if appropriate * Related specifications as appropriate (e.g. if it's an EC2 thing, link the EC2 docs) * Anything else you feel it is worthwhile to refer to

commit_message:
Project-usage spec

Change-Id: I4eb4e17cdc1f0f1826ec8e3b7235517d4a3df6e9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican-specs refs/changes/45/363945/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================= Project Usage API ================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/barbican/+spec/project-usage Add a new administrative API for gathering usage data from a barbican deployment. Problem Description =================== As a Deployer of an OpenStack cloud, there is currently no easy way to gather data about the system usage such as the total amount of secrets stored in the system, total amount of secrets stored by a particular project, etc. Proposed Change =============== This blueprint proposes the addition of a new API endpoint to expose usage metrics on a per-project basis. This new endpoint would be restricted to users with the `barbican:service-admin` role. The API changes are described below. Alternatives ------------ A Deployer could develop custom SQL queries to be run direclty against the Barbican database to gather usage metrics. While this would work, it is not ideal since the database schema will change more often than the API, thus causing these custom solutions to break. Data model impact ----------------- No impact to data models. This change would use existing models to gather usage metrics. REST API impact --------------- Request: .. code-block:: none GET /v1/projects Response: .. code-block:: json { "projects": [ { "project_id": "XXXXXXXXXXXX", "project_quotas_ref": null, "effective_quotas": { "cas": 1000, "consumers": 1000, "containers": 1000, "orders": 1000, "secrets": 1000 }, "usage": { "cas": 0, "consumers": 8, "containers": 8, "orders": 0, "secrets": 37 } }, { "project_id": "YYYYYYYYYYYY", "project_quotas_ref": "https://{barbican_host}/v1/project-quotas/{project_id}", "effective_quotas": { "cas": 1000, "consumers": 1000, "containers": 1000, "orders": 1000, "secrets": -1 }, "usage": { "cas": 0, "consumers": 10, "containers": 100, "orders": 0, "secrets": 865 } } ], "total": 2 } Request: .. code-block:: none GET /v1/projects/{project_id} Response: .. code-block:: json { "project_id": "XXXXXXXXXXXX", "project_quotas_ref": null, "effective_quotas": { "cas": 1000, "consumers": 1000, "containers": 1000, "orders": 1000, "secrets": 1000 }, "usage": { "cas": 0, "consumers": 8, "containers": 8, "orders": 0, "secerets": 37 } } Security impact --------------- This new API should be limited to users with the `barbican:service-admin` role. Notifications & Audit Impact ---------------------------- None. Python and Command Line Client Impact ------------------------------------- python-barbicanclient will have to be updated to use the new API. Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ Minimal since this API is limited to the `barbican:service-admin` role. Other deployer impact --------------------- Deployers can make use of the new API to get usage metrics from their deployment. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Randall Burt Other contributors: Douglas Mendizbal Work Items ---------- Work items or tasks -- break the feature up into the things that need to be done to implement it. Those parts might end up being done by different people, but we're mostly trying to understand the timeline for implementation. Dependencies ============ * Include specific references to specs and/or blueprints in nova, or in other projects, that this one either depends on or is related to. * If this requires functionality of another project that is not currently used by Nova (such as the glance v2 API when we previously only required v1), document that fact. * Does this feature require any new library dependencies or code otherwise not included in OpenStack? Or does it depend on a specific version of library? Testing ======= Please discuss how the change will be tested. We especially want to know what tempest tests will be added. It is assumed that unit test coverage will be added so that doesn't need to be mentioned explicitly, but discussion of why you think unit tests are sufficient and we don't need to add more tempest tests would need to be included. Is this untestable in gate given current limitations (specific hardware / software configurations available)? If so, are there mitigation plans (3rd party testing, gate enhancements, etc). Documentation Impact ==================== What is the impact on the docs team of this change? Some changes might require donating resources to the docs team to have the documentation updated. Don't repeat details discussed above, but please reference them here. References ========== Please add any useful references here. You are not required to have any reference. Moreover, this specification should still make sense when your references are unavailable. Examples of what you could include are: * Links to mailing list or IRC discussions * Links to notes from a summit session * Links to relevant research, if appropriate * Related specifications as appropriate (e.g. if it's an EC2 thing, link the EC2 docs) * Anything else you feel it is worthwhile to refer to

commit_message:
Support concurrent updates on the orders API resource

Currently if a PUT request is made to an existing orders resource, the
updated order metadata is sent as an argument to an enqueued RPC task
to worker nodes. If subsequent PUT requests are made to the same order,
multiple RPC tasks will be enqueued and potentially processed by
multiple worker nodes. Hence the sequence of processing these RPC tasks
is not guaranteed to be the same as the PUT requests were received.
This blueprint seeks to avoid this race condition. A motivation for
this feature is to support reliably updating SSL certificate orders 'in
flight', say to correct a contact email address. Another benefit is
limiting the amount of updates that can be made to a given order,
reducing the possibility of a denial of service attack via the orders
resource.

Change-Id: Ic5db6ed73310b951d73e7f2fe0cbc17711966038
Implements: blueprint api-orders-support-concurrent-updates
APIImpact: Adds 400 response if too many PUT requests to same order
SecurityImpact: Should help mitigate DoS attack on order via PUTs
DocImpact: Update orders resource doc to mention 400 response
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican-specs refs/changes/87/148587/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ===================================================== Support concurrent updates on the orders API resource ===================================================== The Launchpad blueprint is available here: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/barbican/+spec/api-orders-support-concurrent-updates Currently if a PUT request is made to an existing orders resource, the updated order metadata is sent as an argument to an enqueued RPC task to worker nodes. If subsequent PUT requests are made to the same order, multiple RPC tasks will be enqueued and potentially processed by multiple worker nodes. Hence the sequence of processing these RPC tasks is not guaranteed to be the same as the PUT requests were received. This blueprint seeks to avoid this race condition. A motivation for this feature is to support reliably updating SSL certificate orders 'in flight', say to correct a contact email address. Another benefit is limiting the amount of updates that can be made to a given order, reducing the possibility of a denial of service attack via the orders resource. Problem Description =================== Consider this sequence of client interaction with Barbican: 1) Client - POST /orders 2) Barbican - API creates an order record with UUID of 'x', enqueues request to process new order 3) Client - PUT /orders/x, with updated metadata 4) Barbican - API enqueues request to update metadata on existing order 'x' If Step #3 occurs multiple times before an order (especially a long running SSL certificate generation order) is completed, this could result in multiple update order requests pending simultaneously, with multiple worker nodes servicing these tasks concurrently. This could result in order updates applied in a different sequence than they were received, which could result in incorrect updates to the order's metadata. Another concern is that if many order updates are made rapidly to the same order instance, the queue could become clogged with order update requests resulting in a denial of service attack not covered by the proposed quota enforcement feature. Proposed Change =============== Referring to the sequence of steps in the Problem Description above, the proposed solution is to ensure that Step #3 preserves the sequence that order updates are received in, and that Step #4 processes these updates in the correct sequence. This blueprint proposes saving each order update requested to a new one to many relationship off of the orders entity called PendingOrderMetadatum, with a JSON blob attribute to persist the updated order metadata similar to that on the orders entity now. As a PUT update is proposed here, then each update persisted would be a complete and standalone representation of the metadata required at that time. The PendingOrderMetadatum entity would also have a foreign key (FK) back to its order record, and its created_at attribute would be used to determine the sequence of update requests. When an API node receives a PUT /order request, Step 4 would add the requested metadata update to the PendingOrderMetadatum table, and then issue an update order RPC task into the queue. If there are too many unprocessed metadata updates for this order (configurable), PUT attempts would fail with a 400 Bad Request. As mentioned, more than one update order task could be pending in the queue at a time (due to several PUT requests to the same order), raising the possibility that more than one worker node could process a task for the same order concurrently. To prevent this race condition this blueprint proposes that worker nodes perform a select for update on the order record with the SQLAlchemy query's 'nowait' flag set to 'false'. Other workers trying to process this same order record will block, ensuring only one worker at a time can modify the order. When a worker processes an order update task, it would thus perform the following sequence: 1) Perform select for update on the order record. 2) Query PendingOrderMetadatum for the most recent metadata update for the order record. 3) Process this updated metadata for the order (likely via plugin calls). 4) Update the order's original metadata with this metadata update. 5) Remove the metadata from this order from PendingOrderMetadatum up to and including that found in Step #1 (in case the API as added yet more updates). For errors encountered during Step #3, this blueprint proposes loggin the exception noting the issue in the order's sub-status attribute. Alternatives ------------ Barbican could allow for PATCH-ing orders as well, to just update fields that have changed. This would require merging updates with previous update versions. The author's opinion is that this additional effort versus providing requiring clients to provide the entire metadata via PUT requests is not worthwhile. Data model impact ----------------- This blueprint calls for adding a new one to many relationship to the Orders model, called PendingOrderMetadatum, with a epoch attribute called 'created_at' to keep track of when the update was made, a foreign-key (FK) to an order record called 'order_id', and a JSON blob to keep track of the updated order metadata called 'meta'. This blueprint also calls for using select for update on orders entities to ensure that only one Barbican worker node at a time modifies an order. This change would not require a migration. REST API impact --------------- This blueprint keeps the existing PUT v1/orders API, but also responds with a 400 Bad Request if there are too many pending metadata updates for this order. Security impact --------------- None, as the number of pending metadata updates to an order are limited to prevent denial of service attacks. Notifications & Audit Impact ---------------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ This blueprint calls for worker nodes to select for update on orders for new and updated order requests. Worker nodes are very unlikely to contend for the same order record however, but if they do and a process dies, SQLAlchemy should release the lock so other workers could process the request. Other deployer impact --------------------- This blueprint calls for adding a new configuration option called 'max_concurrent_order_updates' to control the maximum amount of order updates allowed at a time, enforced via the API nodes. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: TBD Other contributors: john-wood-w Work Items ---------- The following items would be modified per this blueprint: 1) Add PendingOrderMetadatum entity. 2) Add 'max_concurrent_order_updates' attribute to the etc/barbican/barbican-api.conf file. 3) Modify the orders controller logic for PUTs to a specific order to check for the upper limit on the number of pending metadata updates available (via 'max_concurrent_order_updates'), error out if too many. 4) Modify the API orders PUT logic to add new records for updated metadata to PendingOrderMetadatum. 5) Change the API orders queue RPC task to remove the 'updated_meta' argument. 6) Modify existing BeginTypeOrder task's 'retrieve_entity()' method to select for update on order records, with nowait=false. #3 also requires an update to API documentation. In addition, the existing UpdateOrder's task class would be modified as follows: 1) Remove the 'updated_meta' argument from method calls. 2) In the 'retrieve_entity()' method perform a select for update on order records, with nowait=false. 3) In the 'handle_order()' method, retrieve the latest PendingOrderMetadatum records, setting the most recent one as 'updated_meta'. 4) When all processing in 'handle_order()' is completed, update the order's 'meta' attribute to the 'updated_meta' above, then remove this PendingOrderMetadatum and all older records for this order. Finally, add API controller and database unit tests. Add functional tests to simulate hitting the upper bound on PUT requests to the same order. Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= Database/repository unit tests for the new PendingOrderMetadatum relationship will be needed. Also needed are unit tests of the order controller responding with a 400 once too many PUT requests are made to the same order, and making the revised call to the queue. The BeginTypeOrder and UpdateOrder unit tests will also need to be revised. Finally a negative test to the functional test suite will be needed to simulate many rapid PUT requests being sent to the Barbican orders resource for a given order record. Documentation Impact ==================== As mentioned, API documentation will need to reflect the 400 response from the orders resource if too may PUT request are made to the same order record. References ========== None.

commit_message:
Adding spec for Barbican UI

This patch proposes Horizon plugin for Barbican.

Co-Authored-By: Hemant Chandolia <chandoliahemant@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I23deefee8d82b7e487beb86f34b2ad095b12c79e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican-specs refs/changes/82/323482/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ===================================== Web Interface for Barbican in Horizon ===================================== Launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/barbican/+spec/barbican-horizon-plugin Currently there is no way for a user to interact with Barbican through a web based user interface, as they are used to doing with other OpenStack components. This implementation aims to introduce this interface as an extension of Horizon (the OpenStack Dashboard) and expose all the features of Barbican in a way familiar to users. Problem description =================== In order to increase adoption and usability of Barbican we need to introduce a UI component for users and administrators to interact with Barbican without the need to use the command line. The UI proposed to be built will model all of the features currently available in the Barbican REST API and built using the Horizon plugin architecture to remain in line with other OpenStack UI projects and minimise the amount of new code that needs to be added. Use Cases ---------- 1. An end user wanting to use Barbican with OpenStack who is not comfortable in issuing commands with the python client will use the web user interface to interact with Barbican. 2. An administrator may use the user interface to provide a quick overview of what Barbican has deployed in their OpenStack environment. Proposed change =============== The first step will be to extend the Horizon API to include CRUD operations that are needed to interact with Barbican. Assuming that there are no issues here and API changes/additions are not required to Barbican, we can begin to design/implement the interface. We will aim to minimize the amount of Barbican specific UI code that will need to be maintained by reusing components from Horizon. This will also speed up the development significantly. It is suggested the initial implementation of Barbican UI will include basic CRUD operations on Secrets, Orders, Secret Metadata, Containers, ACL and Certificates. This will be the starting point for development and upon completion this will represent version 1. The ultimate goal,a user should be able to perform all normal interactions with Barbican through the UI with no need for interaction with the python client. Suggestions for further improvement include visualising Barbican resources to provide a quick overview of how resources are deployed. Bugs/Blueprints relating specifically to the Barbican UI will be tracked here: https://launchpad.net/barbican-ui Mockups/Designs will be shared using the OpenStack Invision account located here: https://openstack.invisionapp.com Alternatives ------------ One alternative to this approach is to develop an entirely separate UI specifically for Barbican. We will not use this approach as it does not fall in line with how other projects are managing their user interfaces and this approach would ultimately result in a significantly larger effort with much duplication with Horizon. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- For Barbican, none. The Horizon API will need to be extended to include Create, Read, Update, Delete operations for all features available in the Barbican REST API. However, this extension to the Horizon API will live in the Barbican UI tree not the upstream Horizon tree. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ The Barbican API will be called from the user interface to return information to the user about the current state of Barbican objects and perform new interactions with Barbican. For every action a user performs from the user interface at least one API call to Barbican will need to be made. Other deployer impact --------------------- As the Barbican user interface will be managed and stored outside of the Horizon project deployers will need to pull down the Barbican UI code and add this to their Horizon install. In order to add the Barbican UI to Horizon the deployer will have to copy an enable file to openstack_dashboard/local/enabled/ in their Horizon directory and then run Horizon as they would normally. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Upama Johri Hemant Chandolia Work Items ---------- 1. Extend Horizon API in include Barbican calls 2. CRUD operations on Secrets, Orders, Secret Metadata, Containers, ACL and Certificates. 3. Refine the user experience Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Each commit will be accompanied with unit tests. There will also be functional tests which will be used as part of a cross-functional gate test for Barbican. This additional gate test will be non-voting as failures will not indicate issues with Barbican but instead serves as advanced warning of any changes that could potentially break the UI. Documentation Impact ==================== An installation guide will be required. References ========== None

subject: Add Crypto/HSM MKEK Rotation Support
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-04-30 04:40:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/barbican-specs/commit/e522a5a6e2de26c27c61fb1e86ce15388f3eaca0', 'message': "Add Crypto/HSM MKEK Rotation Support

Currently Barbican has no means to migrate secrets encrypted with a
crypto/HSM-style plugin to a new master key encryption key (MKEK) and
its associated wrapped project KEKs. This blueprint proposes adding a
new Barbican service process that supports completing the rotation of
secrets to a new master key encryption key (MKEK) and a new wrapped
project KEK. This process would be started after deployers, out of

file to reference these new labels, and finally (4) restart the
Barbican nodes. The proposed process would then migrate secrets from
encryption via the old keys to encryption via the new ones.

commit_message:
Add Crypto/HSM MKEK Rotation Support

Currently Barbican has no means to migrate secrets encrypted with a
crypto/HSM-style plugin to a new master key encryption key (MKEK) and
its associated wrapped project KEKs. This blueprint proposes adding a
new Barbican service process that supports completing the rotation of
secrets to a new master key encryption key (MKEK) and a new wrapped
project KEK.

Note that unlike the similarly-named blueprint at
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/barbican/+spec/add-crypto-mkek-rotation-support-lightweight
this blueprint does call for re-encrypting secrets *and* wrapped
project KEKs, so the other blueprint is a 'lightweight' alternative to
this one.

This process would be started after deployers, out of
band: (1) generate new MKEK and HMAC signing keys with a binding to new
labels, and then (2) replicate these keys to other HSMs that may be in
the high availability (HA) group, and then (3) update Barbican's config
file to reference these new labels, and finally (4) restart the
Barbican nodes. The proposed process would then migrate secrets from
encryption via the old keys to encryption via the new ones.

Change-Id: Iccdfca4f309c50b7507f0a0992bec561045784f0
Implements: blueprint add-crypto-mkek-rotation-support
SecurityImpact: Rotates and migrates secrets to new KEKs.
DocImpact: Add information on running KEK migration process.
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican-specs refs/changes/26/178926/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ==================================== Add Crypto/HSM MKEK Rotation Support ==================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/barbican/+spec/add-crypto-mkek-rotation-support Currently Barbican has no means to migrate secrets encrypted with a crypto- style plugin (used with hardware security modules (HSMs)) to a new master key encryption key (MKEK) and its associated wrapped-project KEKs. This blueprint proposes adding a new Barbican service process that supports completing the rotation of secrets to a new master key encryption key (MKEK) and a new wrapped project KEK. This process would be started after deployers, out of band: 1. Generate new MKEK and HMAC signing keys with a binding to new labels, and then 2. Replicate these keys to other HSMs that may be in the high availability (HA) group, and then 3. Update Barbican's config file to reference these new labels, and finally 4. Restart the Barbican nodes. 5. The proposed process would then migrate secrets from encryption via the old keys to encryption via the new ones. Problem Description =================== When a secret is stored in Barbican using the crypto-style plugin, a `KEKDatum` entity (from `barbican.model.models`) is retrieved for the secret's project. If no such entities are found for this project, then the following steps occur: 1. A new `KEKDatum` entity is created for the project and the specific crypto- style plugin with status of `ACTIVE`. The `ACTIVE` status indicates that this entity should be used for secret encryptions from then on. 2. The `bind_kek_metadata()` method is invoked on the crypto plugin. The plugin then creates a project-level KEK that will be used to encrypt new secrets for that project. For the PKCS11 HSM plugin, this is the project KEK that is wrapped/encrypted by the MKEK. 3. Information about this project-level KEK is then added to `plugin_meta` attribute of the new `KEKDatum` entity. 4. When a secret is finally stored, it has a `Secret` entity created for it to hold metadata, and also an associated `EncryptedDatum` entity that holds both the encrypted cypher text for the secret, and a reference to the project-level `KEKDatum` record. 5. Thereafter, new secrets that need to be encrypted for this same project will used this `KEKDatum` entity, with no further attempts made to generate a new entity. Hence the `KEKDatum` entity is associated with project-level KEKs, which in turn are associated with a single MKEK in the HSM. As rotation involves creating a new MKEK (and associated wrapped-project KEKs) on a periodic basis, it follows that a new `KEKDatum` entity needs to be create per project. Due to step (5) above however, the existing `KEKDatum` entity will continue to be used so new secrets will continue to use the (now) older KEK information. In addition existing secrets will continue to be encrypted via the older KEKs. To complete the rotation process, new secrets need to be encrypted using the new KEKs, and existing secrets need to be re-encrypted using the new KEKs. In addition, the UUID for the secrets should not be changed (making the rotation seamless to clients), hence only the associated `EncryptedDatum` entity from step (4) above should change. Also, the process used to migrate secrets to the new set of keys should be resilient, allowing for the process to be re-run if it fails midway. This blueprint details an approach to enable new secrets to utilize the new KEKs, as well as migrating existing secrets to the new KEKs. Proposed Change =============== This blueprint proposes the following steps be taken to complete the KEK rotation and migration effort: 1. Out of band to Barbican (so by deployers), new MKEK and HMAC keys are created in the HSM, with new unique labels. For high availability configurations such keys must be replicated across all HSMs in the cluster. 2. For each API and worker node in the network, update their `/etc/barbican/barbican-api.conf` files' `mkek_label` and `hmac_label` attributes with the new unique labels generated above. 3. Restart the API and worker nodes. 4. Via a new process proposed in this blueprint, query for all `KEKDatum` entities for a specified crypto-style plugin class (e.g. `barbican.plugin.crypto.simple_crypto.SimpleCryptoPlugin`). Secrets encrypted with these old KEKs need to be migrated to the new KEKs, as implemented in the following steps. 5. For all of these queried `KEKDatum` entities set their status to `PENDING`. 6. Again query for `KEKDatum` entities, and then for each one invoke `barbican.plugin.store_crypto.py`'s `_find_or_create_kek_objects()` function. This will create a new `KEKDatum` entity and new wrapped-project KEK per project, using the new MKEK. 7. For each of the queried old `KEKDatum` entities, query for secrets that utilize the entity. 8. For each `Secret` entity found, invoke a new method on the crypto-style plugin contract called 'migrate()', which takes the 'Secret' and its associated `EncryptedDatum` entity's cypher text as well as the old `KEKDatum` entity's information used to encrypt it. It also takes the new `KEKDatum` entity's information. Plugins implement this method by decrypting the secret internally to the HSM with the old wrapped-project KEK, and then re-encrypting with the new one. 9. After the secret is re-encrypted as above, update its `EncryptedDatum` entity with the new cypher text, and with a reference to the new project-level `KEKDatum` record. 10. Info log the UUID of the migrated secret to produce a record of the migration. The proposed process would be implemented as a Python `barbican.cmd` script and added as a `pbr` entry point in the `setup.cfg` file, and hence available as a callable command once Barbican is deployed. To preserve data integrity steps 4 and 5, step 6, and steps 8 and 9 should be performed in a database transaction. A race condition is possible in step #6 above, as a new secret POST-ed to Barbican after all `KEKDatum` entities are set to `PENDING` would also result in the `_find_or_create_kek_objects()` function being invoked, possibly resulting in more than one `ACTIVE` `KEKDatum` entity for a given project ID. Hence a secret might be using a different wrapped-project KEK than secrets added after this step. However since these `ACTIVE` entities all use the new MKEK, this race condition is not critical to mitigate. The current code does not support the possiblity of more than one `ACTIVE` `KEKDatum` entity however. Hence this blueprint proposes modifying the source in `barbican.model.repositories.py`, in class `KEKDatumRepo` and method `find_or_create_kek_datum()` as follows: 1. Add a filter to the query: `query.order_by(models.KEKDatum.updated_at.desc())`. 2. Change the query `kek_datum = query.one()` to `kek_datum = query.first()`, to only return the most recent `ACTIVE` entity. 3. Change the try/except logic to `if not kek_datum:...`. Alternatives ------------ Rather than implementing a manual secret migration process, we could instead have checked secrets when they are read to see if they need to be migrated, and then automatically migrated them. The plugin itself might have detected if its configuration changed at __init__() time and then performed an automatic migration for all of its secrets. However, automatic migrations would be problematic in a complete HA Barbican network, with multiple API and worker nodes potentially trying to generate and convert wrapped-project KEKs and secrets concurrently. The proposed approach only has a single process performing the conversions which should be more safe. Data model impact ----------------- No data model changes are needed for the proposed solution, only changes to the repositories used to query the data model. Data migrations will be required as detailed in the Proposed Change section above. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- The proposed solution completes necessary key rotation processes by migrating secrets to being encrypted via new KEKs. There are improbable but possible data loss risks with the proposed approach however, since encrypted secret information from the old KEKs is replaced with encrypted information from the new KEKs. If the database update fails and corrupts this record, the secret would be lost. Preserving the old encrypted information for the secret to allow recovering this data later would not be acceptable if the MKEK and associated wrapped-project KEKs were compromised. If this risk is deemed unacceptable, an additional check after the secret's encrypted data is updated could be made to test the decrypt, before migrating the next secret. This check would need to be made internal to the HSM to avoid having decrypted secrets in memory. Running the proposed migration process multiple times without new MKEKs will produce additional `KEKDatum` entities for each project ID with no benefit. This process, which will not be fast if there are many secrets to migrate, would have to be run many times before resources exhaustion would be a concern. Notifications & Audit Impact ---------------------------- A log of each secret migrated is produced by the proposed process, which could be used to prove to auditors that a migration/rotation occurred. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ The proposed process could take a long time to process if there are many secrets to migrate, and thus it would represent an load on the database impacting all other operations. This process would be called quite infrequently however (maybe 1 to 4 times a year). Other deployer impact --------------------- The proposed process would be executed as a new executable command available after deployment Barbican. The proposed changes would not require updates to the configuration file schema, but would require schema updates to provide new MKEK and HMAC key labels. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- TBD Work Items ---------- The proposed work items are: 1. Modify the source in `barbican.model.repositories.py`, in class `KEKDatumRepo` and method `find_or_create_kek_datum()` per the Proposed Change section. 2. Create a Python command script to implement the 10 steps in the Proposed Change section. 3. Add unit testing to cover the new code lines. 4. Add integration unit test that, using the default `simple_crypto.py` plugin and an in-memory SQLite database, first creates a few known secrets with the default MEK in the config file, and then modifies this MEK, and then executes the migration script logic. The secrets should be decrypted and verified for accuracy. The `KEKDatum` entities that are non-`ACTIVE` are then removed. The secrets should again be decrypted and verified for accuracy, which proves the migration of all secrets to the new `KEKDatum` record occurred successfully. 5. Document the overall key rotation and migration process, including the usage of the new migration command script. Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= No DevStack functional tests are expected at this time. Once an HSM gate job is added, a future blueprint add tests will be added. Documentation Impact ==================== The last work item details the required documentation. References ========== None.

commit_message:
Container ACL and Fetch API

Implement Container ACL's and API to retrieve secrets that will work
for the Generic Heat Template for the Applications Catalog workflow.

APIImpact

Change-Id: Idb5e09ac593282380ae1488c0cffc803259f5974
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican-specs refs/changes/04/190404/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Container ACL and Fetch API ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/barbican/+spec/container-acl As part of the Generic Heat Template for the Applications Catalog workflow, We need some way for Instances to be able to be given read access to Barbican Containers of secrets so that they can fetch the secrets they need to operate properly and no longer hard code secrets into the templates or pass them in parameters where they enter several sql databases. Problem Description =================== There needs to be a way to set ACL's on Barbican Containers such that a Keystone User can be granted read access to all of the secrets the container points to. Also, the adding and removing of User's to containers must be atomic and race free to enable a proper Heat Resource for OS::Barbican::ContainerACL to be created. Lastly, there needs to be a simple API endpoint to allow fetching of a secret if all you know is a containername/uuid, and a secret name in the container. All together these pieces will enable a Heat template to create an autoscaling group that launches and destroys Instance Stacks on the fly based on load that: * Launch a new instance using the new precreateInstanceUser=True flag * Use an OS::Barbican::ContainerACL resource to enable read access to the instance_user_id associated with that instance * Create a SoftwareDeployment resource that depends on the ContainerACL completing that: * curl's the nova metadata server to retrieve a valid Keystone Token and Service Catalog * curl's the Barbican specified in the previous step with the token, and fetches a specific named secret out of a specified container by name. This will allow truly generic, cloud scale templates to be written that can be submitted to the Application Catalog. Proposed Change =============== First, the API must be extended to support atomically adding and removing read only access to secrets in containers. Heat will autoscale up and down and if the ACL is one document that has to be downloaded/uploaded as a whole, there is a race that will break security. So a restful API will be needed. Proposed solution: POST '{"access":"read"}' & DELETE /v1/container/<container_uuid>/user/<USER_ID> Second, the API must be extended to support simple fetching of secrets if all the user know's is the container's name and the name of the secret inside the container. Container ID's are unique to the cloud they are on, and thus can not be used to make generic templates that are redistributable. Proposed solution: GET /v1/container/<container_name or container_id>/secret/<secret_name> Alternatives ------------ See the VM Integration spec. It was discussed at the summit and this approach was recommended instead. Data model impact ----------------- A new table storing container_id, user_id, and permission will need to be added to the database. REST API impact --------------- * /v1/container/<container_uuid>/user/<USER_ID> * Method type: POST * Add permissions to a user to access a container * Response codes 200, 401 * The data sent to the endpoint will be a json document that looks like: '{"access":"read"}'. Only access will be currently supported. If the body Is blank, then read access will be assumed. * If the ACL doesn't exist, the first POST to the ACL will automatically Create it. * /v1/container/<container_uuid>/user/<USER_ID>/<permissiontype> * Method type: DELETE * Delete permissions for a user to access a container * Response codes 200, 401 * /v1/container/<container_name or container_id>/secret/<secret_name> * Method type: GET * Download a secret's raw data from the given container by secret name * Response codes 200, 401 Security impact --------------- This change allows a user to delegate access to secrets they maintain to other users. Notifications & Audit Impact ---------------------------- None known. Other end user impact --------------------- python-barbicanclient should be updated to support these features as well Performance Impact ------------------ Using of the new API will put additional load on the Barbican servers. Other deployer impact --------------------- None known. Developer impact ---------------- No known developer impact. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- I don't know the answer yet to this. There are developers already working on ACL's. I don't want to step on their toes. I do have existing code that implement the fetch secret by container/secret name that was created as part of the vm integration spec. I'd be happy to adapt that to meet this spec. Primary assignee: kevpn Other contributors: ? Work Items ---------- * Implement Barbican Container ACL database * Implement Barbican Container ACL rest API * Implement Barbican API to fetch secrets through the Container ACL. Dependencies ============ No dependencies. It itself is a dependency though. Testing ======= I believe unit tests will be sufficient for this, as the api's are all very simple. Documentation Impact ==================== The additional API's will need to be documented. References ========== This was discussed at the summit and also with the Barbican PTL and some members of the OpenStack API team on the API irc channel.

commit_message:
Set the lower limit of api_version for volume_type

In boot server API, the volume_type is supported by microversion 2.67.
Therefore, the lower limit of the volume_type should be added to the CLI
command, otherwise an exception will occur.

Co-Authored-By: Eric Xie <eric_xiett@163.com>

Closes-Bug: #1829854
Change-Id: Ie909c16568b017ca0acc802194140da7bece76c5
